content:
âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice clash, I thought the description was a bit long, but it isn't too hard to read it all, and then most of it is the detailed explanation which is helpful but can be skimmed over in Fastest mode.

Nice clash, I thought the description was a bit long, but it isn't too hard to read it all, and then most of it is the detailed explanation which is helpful.

The only problem I've found is that I tested the tests/validators and found an issue where if a clasher was not careful with taking the absolute value of the differences between consecutive stations then your choices of tests/validators can lead to a problem. The specific problem case is if the clasher remembers to take the absolute value of the x distance, but takes the raw value of the y distance. Then they will pass 100% of your current test cases, but fail 80% of your current validators!

It would be good to swap at least a couple of these pairs around to remove this possibility and allow such an error to be debugged in-clash. Example Ruby code below.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: The statement is clear and concise. As you precised the rules to calculate diagonal and straight distance I don't see any possible ambiguity.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good puzzle, easy to solve in <5min.

Thank you for this contribution. I think it is going to be quite a challenge for the 15 minutes of clash of code and also a good test for the more advanced coders.

One of the criteria for acceptance is that it needs to be solvable within 5 minutes for the clash of code. It could help to make this solvable more quickly to clarify the line "Diagonal distance between two diagonally aligned points is the difference between the 2 x-coordinates (or y-coordinates).".

My proposal :
 - Diagonal distance between two diagonally aligned points is the _minimum_ difference between the 2 x-coordinates (or y-coordinates).
- Straight distance is the maximum distance between the 2 x-coordinates (or y-coordinates) less any diagonal distance.

Cover picture
* Suggest to upload a cover picture for the puzzle.

Cases
* Validator 3: I'd just like to point out that the station (2, -1) lies on the diagonal line joining (3, 0) and (-1, -4). It'll be a confusing station map if this is a real case (though it's still not as confusing as those for Test/Validator 4 and 5, where many lines cross over each other) ðŸ˜†

Thanks.

Thank you
It's a clash of code, so no cover picture.
I thought it would be too easy or too short for a puzzle.

I updated the last testcases (they were totally random, because lazy me). Now they're more "logical".
Thank you, updated it. I hope it's clearer now

n = gets.to_i
a = n.times.map{ gets.split.map { |x| x.to_i } }
s = d = 0
a.each_cons(2).each do |(x, y), (u, v)|
  dx = (u - x).abs
  dy = (v - y)
  md = [dx, dy].min
  ms = dx + dy - 2 * md
  d += md
  s += ms
end
puts [s, d]*" "
Thank you, I fixed it (just changed the order of the stations for test 5)

Nice, I've approved now.

One other suggestion I just thought of, would be to edit the station diagrams in the example such that instead of 'o' for each station you could have the digit you later refer to them by '0,1,2,3'. I thought this might help make the diagram easier to understand, but see what you think.
Oops, I must be dreaming when I thought this was a puzzle. Sorry about that!
